titlestmt.titleproper: Register of the Ardashīr Zāhidī papers
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Heather Hughes

change.item: July 24, 2017: Collection processed by Heather Hughes.

physdesc.extent: 273 manuscript boxes, 75 oversize boxes, 924 computer files (1.6 GB)

did.abstract: Correspondence, speeches and writings, interview transcripts, financial records, photographs, video and sound recordings, printed matter, and computer disks relating to Ardeshir Zahedi's diplomatic career during the Pahlavi era in Iran. Zahedi served as Ambassador to the United States, Ambassador to the United Kingdom, and as Minister of Foreign Affairs during the reign of Mohammad Reza Pahlavi. The collection also contains the papers of Ardeshir's father, Fazlollah Zahedi, a general who occupied the post of prime minister. Topics of note include: Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, Iranian foreign relations, Iranian-American relations, the Cold War, the events of August 1953, the 1977 Hanafi Siege, and Iranian dissent.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research; materials must be requested at least two business days in advance of intended use.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Hoover Institution Archives.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Ardashīr Zāhidī papers, [Box no.], Hoover Institution Archives.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: Materials were acquired by the Hoover Institution Archives in 2009, with an additional increment received in 2016.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Materials may have been added to the collection since this finding aid was prepared. To determine if this has occurred, find the collection in Stanford University's online catalog at http://searchworks.stanford.edu/. Materials have been added to the collection if the number of boxes listed in the catalog is larger than the number of boxes listed in this finding aid.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Ardeshir Zahedi (Ardashīr Zāhidī) was an Iranian statesman and diplomat during Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi's reign (1941-1979). He was born in 1928 to Fazlollah Zahedi and Khadijeh Pirnia, who both stemmed from significant political backgrounds.

Fazlollah Zahedi, one of the generals who overthrew Mohammed Mossadegh in 1953, occupied the post of prime minister from 1953 to 1955. Prior to that, Fazlollah Zahedi had a significant military and political career, participating in military campaigns such as the suppression of the Jangal movement and the arrest of Sheikh Kha’zal Khan. During World War II, he was interned by the British in Palestine from 1941 to 1945, under the allegation of collaborating with German forces. After his internment, Fazlollah Zahedi held posts of Chief of National Police and Minister of Interior. Meanwhile, Ardeshir obtained his Bachelor of Science from Utah State University in 1950, and worked for the Point Four Program upon his return to Iran. Both Ardeshir and Fazlollah Zahedi found themselves at odds with the Mossadegh government, and during the turbulent events of August 1953, Ardeshir Zahedi stayed close to his father’s side. These events, known as the 28 Mordad coup, resulted in the overthrow of Mossadegh and the appointment of Fazlollah Zahedi as Prime Minister. However, Fazlollah Zahedi’s term was short-lived, as he was forced to resign in 1955. He was then appointed Ambassador to the United Nations in Geneva, and lived in Switzerland until his death in 1963. Ardeshir Zahedi maintained close relations with the Shah, and married his eldest daughter, Shahnaz Pahlavi, in 1957. They had one child, Mahnaz Zahedi, and divorced in 1964. Ardeshir Zahedi held his first diplomatic post in the United States from 1959 to 1961, and was then appointed Ambassador to the United Kingdom from 1962 to 1966. From 1966 to 1971 he served as Minister of Foreign Affairs. Ardeshir Zahedi was appointed Ambassador to the United States a second time in 1973, and occupied this position until the Iranian Revolution forced the Shah from power in 1979. Ardeshir Zahedi tried to find political asylum for the Shah and his family, and was present for his death and funeral in Cairo. In the wake of Iran’s transformation from a monarchy to an Islamic republic, Ardeshir Zahedi has resided in Montreux, Switzerland, occasionally providing interviews and commentary on Iranian politics. He has spent the last several years working on his memoirs, a multi-volume project.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The Ardashīr Zāhidī papers contain correspondence, speeches and writings, interview transcripts, financial records, photographs, video and sound recordings, printed matter, and computer disks relating to Ardeshir Zahedi's diplomatic career during the Pahlavi era. Zahedi served as Ambassador to the United States, Ambassador to the United Kingdom, and as Minister of Foreign Affairs during the reign of Mohammad Reza Pahlavi. The collection also contains the papers of Ardeshir's father, Fazlollah Zahedi, a general who occupied the post of prime minister. Topics of note include: Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, Iranian foreign relations, Iranian-American relations, the Cold War, the events of August 1953, the 1977 Hanafi Siege, and Iranian dissent.

The Faz̤l Allāh Zāhidī Papers document Fazlollah's military and political career, his internment in Palestine during World War II, his tenure as prime minister, and his appointment as diplomat to the United Nations in Geneva. They also contain materials related to Ardeshir's youth and marriage.
The Minister of Foreign Affairs File includes correspondence, transcripts, notes, and reports related to meetings with foreign officials, dignitaries, and heads of state.

Ardeshir's second appointment as Ambassador to the United States spanned the presidencies of Richard Nixon, Gerald Ford, and Jimmy Carter, and ended with the Shah's abdication. The Ambassador to the United States File documents this period and includes embassy documents and Ardeshir's correspondence. Ardeshir corresponded with a wide range of people, including U.S. and Iranian government officials, and members of the press.

Since resigning from his diplomatic post, Ardeshir has resided in Montreux, Switzerland. The Career after Diplomacy File demonstrates his engagement in editing and providing resources for works about the Pahlavi era, drafts and documents compiled for his memoirs, and editorial and interview materials.

The Photographs series includes photographs and albums from Fazlollah's youth through Ardeshir's second appointment in the United States. Although different stages of Ardeshir's life and career are depicted, including his wedding and his first appointment in the United States, his second appointment in the United States is the most documented aspect of his life. Other areas of interest include photographs from the 1953 coup and of the Pahlavis.

odd.head: General Note
odd.p: Persian names of individuals have been Romanized according to Library of Congress standards as well as common usage.
Dates mostly follow the Gregorian calendar; Iranian calendar dates are accompanied by conversions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes military identification document with accompanying papers, documents promoting Zahedi to "sarlashgar" and recognizing his service at Delimqan, diplomatic passport, and documents appointing him as Ambassador to the United Nations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes meeting transcripts and notes, reports, talking points, memoranda, correspondence, shared statements between countries, speeches, and financial records. Subjects include Middle East politics, the Persian Gulf, disputed territories in the Persian Gulf, the Arab-Israeli Conflict, communism and the Soviet Union, arms, oil, and Iran's military and economic relations. Materials are largely in Persian, with some documents in Arabic, English, French, and German.
Arranged according to orginal order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Subjects include the Arab-Israeli Conflict, the Persian Gulf, Yemen, the Federation of South Arabia, Iraq, Central Treaty Organization (CENTO), and oil. Includes notes and subject information from Roberts's visit to Iran, summaries of meetings from previous folder, communications between Zahedi and Abbas Aram, communications with the Department of Code, the Iranian Embassy in Baghdad, and the Iraqi Embassy in Tehran.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes notes from state visit discussions; schedules from state visits of the Emir of Kuwait to Iran; reports from the National Iranian Oil Company, the Iranian Embassy in Kuwait, the Department of Code, and other governmental departments, and reports on various issues related to Iran-Kuwait relations including visas to Kuwait and Iranian workers in Kuwait, fishing in the Persian Gulf, and the naming of the Persian Gulf; communications with the Kuwait Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Iranian Foreign Affairs, and the Department of Housing and Urban Development; and texts from treaties and agreements between Iran and Kuwait.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Documents related to a meeting between the Shah, President Ayub Khan of Pakistan, and Prime Minister Süleyman Demirel of Turkey. Includes transcipts from discussions, shared statement from the three leaders, Zahedi's notes and talking points, as well as notes from other individuals, and hotel information. Topics of discussion include Regional Cooperation for Development (RCD), CENTO, Western and Soviet influence in the Middle East, and Arab countries in the Middle East.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, documents, memoranda, notes, reports, speeches, and printed matter from Zahedi's second appointment as Ambassador to the United States. Correspondence files include accompanying printed matter and Iranian government correspondence. Original order, correspondence groups, and folder titles have been maintained, and many individuals have multiple correspondence files.

Subjects include Iranian-American relations, Iranian foreign policy, Middle Eastern politics, Iran and the Shah as portrayed in the media, political developments in the United States, oil and energy, economic issues, the purchase of arms, human rights in Iran, embassy activities and social events, the Hanafi Siege, Iranian dissent in the United States, unrest in Iran, state visits, and gifts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Sharaf ʻarz̤ī pīshgāh-i mubārak-i Shāhanshāh Āryā Mihr."

Includes reports and communications addressed or forwarded to the Shah, Zahedi's correspondence, Zahedi's notes, communications between the embassy and the Special Bureau, media reports, some photographs, and accompanying printed material. Materials are mostly in English and Persian, with some items in Spanish and French. Correspondents include American politicians, military and intelligence officials, journalists and people working in news media, academics, and business leaders, as well as diplomats and political figures from other countries. Many of the correspondents have files in the following correspondence groups, and some of the letters are duplicated within these correspondence groupings.
Iranian correspondents include Yūsuf Akbar, Assad Homayoun, Abbas Ali Khalatbari, Nosratollah Moeinian, ʻAbbās Ordubādi, and Jamshīd Tavallalī.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed compilations of telegraphs from the embassy to the Vizārat-i Umūr-i Khārijah (Ministry of Foreign Affairs), Vizārat-i Darbār-i Shāhanshāhī (Ministry of Royal Court), and Daftar-i Makhṣūṣ (Special Bureau). Books are indexed with tables of contents, with subject titles for each telegraph.

Subjects include American foreign relations, American internal politics, Watergate, American media reporting, oil, Middle Eastern politics, the Arab-Israeli conflict, Iranian foreign relations, Soviet politics, state visits, social events, and meetings.

Also includes copies of decrees and orders related to his father (1925-1958), most of which are found in other research files.

Other areas of interest include photographs from the 1953 coup and of the Pahlavis.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These albums, arranged chrologically, largely document social events hosted by Ardeshir Zahedi at the Iranian Embassy. Events include dinners and parties given for diplomats, politicians (American and Iranian), military officials, holidays, and members of the Pahlavi family.

The following people appear in multiple albums: Yousef Akbar, George Allen, Pearl Bailey, Birch and Marvella Bayh, Edward Brooke, Bunny and Philip W. Buchen, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Catto, Huang Chen, Deena Clark, Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Coyne, Arlene Dahl, Ymelda Dixon, Sidney Epstein, Abbas Ghaffari, Barry Goldwater, Bill Graves, Joanne Herring, Fereydoon Hoveyda, Jacob K. Kazemian, Edward Kennedy, Begum and Sahabzada Yaqub Khan, Henry and Nancy Kissinger, Jacques Kosciusko-Morizet, Irving Levine, Mr. and Mrs. Clark MacGregor, Peter Malatesta, Mike Mansfield, Mara and Sylvan Marshall, J. Rogers, Mr. and Mrs. Carl Rowan, Jane and Kenneth Rush, Abdullah Salah, David Schoumacher, Count and Countess de Segonzac, Marion H. Smoak, Garnett Stackelberg, Helen and Robert S. Strauss, Stuart Symington, Wilhelm Wachtmeister, Bennetta and Walter Washington, and Miss Yazdan-Panah.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes correspondence, memoranda, writings, photographs, video and recordings, computer disks, and printed material, mostly from Zahedi’s time in Switzerland. A few materials are related to Fazlollah Zahedi’s political career and Ardeshir Zahedi’s second appointment as Ambassador to the United States, but the bulk of the material stems from his time in Switzerland, and includes drafts and photographs and documents assembled for his multi-volume memoir. More recent photographs portray public appearances, and his family and social life. Zahedi is also an active public figure, and his numerous television and radio appearances are documented in the video and sound recordings. The printed material includes Persian language magazines, many of which feature Zahedi, and Persian language books, mostly about the Pahlavi period.
